summary: all IFN-Is bind to a common heterodimeric cell surface receptor. Activated STAT1 and STAT2 form a trimolecular complex with interferon regulatory factor 9 (IRF9) binding of IFN- to its unique receptor results in the formation of STAT1 homodimers. IFN-I, as well as IFN-II, can activate additional signaling pathways (reviewed in references 41 and 99) however, the nature of these pathways and their biological significance is not yet well understood. LCMV is a rare cause of meningoencephalitis in adults and fetuses. lymphocytic choriomeningitis (LCM) is characterized by seizures and mononuclear cell infiltrates in the meninges and choroid plexus (4, 12) the development of LCM is dependent on CD8+ effector T cells (12, 24, 29–31, 37, 79) but does not require CD4+ T helper cells (24, 58) following peripheral infection, LCMV is cleared within 10 to 12 days postinfection despite the central roles of STAT1, STAT2 and IRF9 in IFN-I signaling, there has been only limited investigation of the roles that these factors play in LCMV infection. however, further studies are needed to clarify the role of IFN-III in the disease.
